awd_titl_txt: Convergence QL: Workshop Series: Cross- Sector Connections in Quantum Leap
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
Quantum Information Science and Engineering (QISE) has made remarkable progress, heralding promise for revolutionary new technologies in quantum sensing, communication, computation and cryptography. Recent advances bring the promise of QISE into marketable technologies with the potential for a sustained and profound societal impact. A successful technology leap requires investment in a trained workforce adept in the basic quantum sciences as well as proficient in the necessary engineering fields, informed about the broader issues of developing quantum science into marketable quantum devices. This is an optimal time to explore new, more effective ways of coupling academic and industrial research programs, promoting convergence of disciplines, resources and sectors in this endeavor. This project addresses these issues by developing a series of workshops constituting the QISE Network (QISE-NET): a community of tightly integrated university-industry partners, focused on leading-edge QISE projects. These associates comprise three-person teams of university faculty, industrial researchers, and a graduate student serving as the pivotal component of the group. QISE-NET serves as a model for a new approach to graduate student education as well as truly collaborative university-industry interactions, including the selection of projects, yearly workshops, and student mentoring activities. The program creates new employment opportunities for students along with company positions and start-up ventures. This Project promotes Convergence by offering a way to educate, train and nurture a cohort of industry-academia partnerships between the convergent disciplines of Materials Science Theory, Materials Science Experiment, Device Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, Computer Science, and Industrial Research.

Technical Abstract: 
This activity helps to create a distinctive and critically-needed intellectual infrastructure for students studying the convergent QISE disciplines. By linking the talents, resources and approaches of both the academic and industrial environment, QISE-NET is able to create and leverage an intellectually broad community of researchers to generate the new science, engineering and marketable QISE technologies of the future. By demonstrating how students' academic work can be enabled and broadened through access to the resources, systems and team-based approaches available in industrial research laboratories, QISE-NET establishes new models of university-industry collaboration, while providing a more cogent program for graduate student education in QISE. Proposals are submitted through a program website, and announced using broad electronic distribution through academic and professional society organizations, as well as through corporate network distribution. They are evaluated by an external advisory board consisting of academic and industrial researchers spanning a broad range of science and technology. Yearly workshops form the principal means of communications among the various projects and serve to knit the network. Participants share research results, and understand the different best practices that produce effective interactions. An education specialist from a NSF center conducts independent, anonymous assessments from the participants, and provides a mechanism to improve the effectiveness of both the program and workshops. The QISE-NET will generate outstanding, leading-edge scientific results with applicability to new, marketable technologies, and serve to strengthen collaborations between academia and industry. This Project promotes Convergence by offering a way to educate, train and nurture a cohort of industry-academia partnerships between the convergent disciplines of Materials Science Theory, Materials Science Experiment, Device Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, Computer Science, and Industrial Research.

por.por_cntn:
QISE-NET Final Summary

 

The Quantum Information Science and Engineering Network (QISE-NET), co-led by the University of Chicago and Harvard University, was a one-of-a-kind national training program for graduate students pursuing careers in quantum science and engineering. The Quantum Leap Big Idea was formulated as a cross-NSF activity focused on advancing the development of quantum technologies. The ?Triplets? teams funded under the Quantum Leap built cohorts, with each triplet comprising 1) a university PI, 2) an industrial partner or national laboratory and 3) a graduate student, working together for up to three years. Together, the triplet cohorts formed the QISE-NET network. This novel approach to integrating research, education, and technology transfer was highly convergent and cross-cutting in nature, and included triplets spanning fields as diverse as materials science, chemistry, device engineering, physics, and computer science, and research teams from academia, companies, and national laboratories. 

 

The primary motivation for this initiative was the missing pipeline: the U.S. is currently not educating sufficient numbers of students with the knowledge, understanding and expertise in multiple convergent fields to fuel the current and future workforce required for the second quantum revolution. The secondary motivation arose from the need to increase convergent academia-industry and academia-national laboratory interactions to advance the technological goals of the Quantum Leap initiative by cross-sector sharing and leveraging of facilities, expertise, and scientific and technical challenges. This network of triplets provided a unique, critically-needed student experience in quantum science. Students were the primary recipients of the support, working within a focused academic-industry or academia-national laboratory collaboration which included thesis development, specific research goals, visits to national laboratory or industry partner sites, and network-level mentoring opportunities. QISE-NET students received stipends to facilitate their participation within the network. 

 

Research projects originated from each of the participating triplets, with proposals submitted to QISE-NET. Proposals were collected through an open, web-based mechanism via the QISE-NET website (https://qisenet.uchicago.edu/). The selection process aimed to identify proposals most likely to create conditions for successful collaboration and integration within a network of triplets in pursuit of the Quantum Leap goals. 

 

A successful technology leap requires investment in a trained workforce adept in the basic quantum sciences, proficient in necessary engineering fields, and informed about the broader issues of developing quantum science into marketable quantum devices or applications. This was an optimal time to explore new, more effective ways of coupling academic and industrial research programs, promoting the convergence of disciplines, resources, and sectors. QISE-NET served as a model for a new approach to graduate student education and training as well as truly collaborative university-industry and university-national laboratory interactions, including the selection of projects, yearly workshops, and student mentoring activities. The program created new employment opportunities for students in companies and start-up ventures. This project promoted Convergence by offering a way to educate, train and nurture a cohort of industry-academia partnerships between convergent disciplines, including materials science theory and experiment, device engineering, physics, chemistry, and computer science.

 

Over the lifespan of the QISE-NET program:

  • 79 students were supported in triplet cohorts
  • 34 universities, 9 industry partners, and 13 national and government laboratories were engaged in the cohorts
  • 30 students received or will receive their PhD by the end of 2022 and 49 students are on course to complete their PhD in the next few years
  • 194 papers have been accepted or are in review in scientific journals
  • 239 presentations were made by students at scientific conferences

 

This program has already had an impact in reaching students who are planning non-academic technical careers in industry and communicating the opportunities within these career paths to the broader community. A growing number of QISE-NET awardees have accepted post-PhD jobs at this time with seven in academia, two in government labs, one at a quantum-focused non-profit, and eighteen in industry.

 

QISE-NET alumni have taken positions at a number of organizations, including: two postdocs at MIT, one postdoc at the University of Pennsylvania, one postdoc at the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing at the University of California at Berkeley, one postdoc at Caltech, one postdoc at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, one postdoc at the University of Chicago, one postdoc at Oak Ridge National laboratory, one at Los Alamos National Laboratory, one at SRI International, two at Google, one at Qorvo, Inc, two at Intel, one at Booze Allen Hamilton, one at Rigetti Computing, one at Xanadu, one at IonQ, two at IBM, one at Quantinuum, one with Amazon Web Services, one at Meta Systems, one at L3Harris Space and Airborne Systems, and one with Clark+Elbing. One QISE-NET graduate started a company, qBraid.

Modified by: David D Awschalom
